Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Laser-Assisted Surface Cooling Enhancement (LASCE)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1403508/1402587
Aguilar/Trujillo

This grant provides funding for studying and developing a non-intrusive method to enhance local heat transfer between a target surface and a cooling fluid. The approach takes advantage of thermocavitation bubbles, which are formed when continuous wave (CW) laser light is properly focused within highly absorbing liquid thin films. These bubbles form and collapse within microseconds, vigorously agitating the liquid and enhancing heat transfer. This phenomenon is called Laser-Assisted Surface Cooling Enhancement (LASCE). The PIs preliminary estimates show that heat transfer enhancement is as great as that of phase change (evaporation/boiling), which is the current upper limit to liquid-based cooling systems. LASCE may also match or exceed the performance obtained using micro-modified structures, but without implementing any type of surface modification. Also, CW lasers are often less complex lasing media, cheaper and simpler than pulse lasers, and can control the frequency of bubble formation simply by modulating their output power. The potential impact of this project, therefore, is in novel ways of controlling surface heat. This has implications for systems ranging from laser surgery to combustion engine devices.

This study encompasses collaborative experimental and computational research between University of California-Riverside and University of Wisconsin-Madison aimed at studying and quantifying the: 1) balance between the heat input to induce thermal cavitation and the cooling produced by enhanced convection; 2) sensitivity of the resulting fluid flow to the operating parameters of the laser and; 3) physics of interaction between multiple cavitation events and its effect on enhanced convective cooling. Based on highly accurate numerical simulations and detailed measurement techniques, a thorough examination of the physics underpinning the most desirable heat transfer conditions will be sought, which is essential in optimizing the operation of LASCE. This will be followed by an equally important objective, which aims to explore LACSE's suitability for applications where surface modification is impossible, such as skin (scalp) cooling during laser therapy across a novel transparent cranial implant ("Window to the Brain") developed at UCR. The success of this project will open the door to many transformative applications of optical thermocavitation aimed at low-temperature combustion strategies for mitigating the levels of NOx and particulate matter emissions to improve engine efficiency as well as transdermal drug delivery for diverse biomedical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our collaborative work with the University of California-Riverside concerns the development of a non-intrusive method to enhance local heat transfer between a target surface and a cooling fluid by optical thermo-cavitation, leading to what we call Laser-Assisted Surface Cooling Enhancement (LASCE). The underlying hypothesis is that frequent and rapid creation and collapse of cavitation bubbles agitate the liquid non-intrusively and enhance local convection heat transfer. By directing the focal point of a laser into an absorbing fluid, superheating and subsequent rapid cavitation occur. The growth and collapse of a cavitation vapor bubble will induce a local flow that results in increased overall convective heat transfer. Our contribution to this joint effort is in the numerical simulation of this process of bubble growth and collapse and the analysis of the associated physics. Additionally, a significant effort in this project has been the development of new numerical tools for simulating these types of flows, which are characterized by phase change.

 

Bubble growth process is well-known to be comprised of an initial inertia-controlled phase followed by a heat-transfer controlled period. The vast majority of 3D numerical approaches presented in the literature are shown in the present work to be inaccurate in the inertia-controlled stage of the growth process, while their accuracy remains high in the latter stage of bubble growth. This has important implications as the fraction of time spent in the inertia-controlled phase increases with the intensity of the boiling process. The reason for the inaccuracy is found to be the inability of various numerical methods to capture the time variation of the interface temperature and its coupling with the bubble pressure. To understand this behavior quantitatively a new flow solver was developed based on a compressible saturated treatment of the bubble contents, coupled to a generalized form of the Rayleigh-Plesset equation, and an Arbitrary-Lagrangian-Eulerian solution of the spherically-symmetric liquid phase energy equation.

Concerning bubble collapse, an interesting finding of this work is the connection between the momentum and energy dynamics in bubble collapse. This is explicitly shown by relating the rate of change in vapor pressure to the magnitude of interfacial vapor velocity. Pressure is known to play a crucial role in the momentum conservation, and vapor velocity influences the energy balance of the bubble directly. In the thermal collapse regime (post-initial transient), the slow bubble contraction is balanced almost perfectly by condensation, and the change in vapor properties becomes negligible. However, at higher collapse speeds, the bubble contraction and condensation are significantly different, resulting in a pronounced value for the interfacial vapor velocity. For the inertial collapse or most severe collapse, the balance between bubble contraction and condensation is reestablished, except for the final period, which occupies a tiny fraction of the entire collapse process. Since the time scales for this violent process are extremely short, the thermal boundary layer is minute generating a large liquid heat flux that nearly matches the condensation rate. Consequently, the vapor contents are nearly constant until the final moment of collapse.

Besides the dissemination of results in journal articles and conference presentations, the PI in the present project was part of an international effort to educate students in the area of computation of two-phase flows. This effort was materialized as a series of two workshops, 1st and 2nd Workshop on Advances in CFD and MD Modeling of Interface Dynamics in Capillary Two-Phase Flows, October 2016 & 2017, held at the EPFL in Lausanne, Switzerland. The material presented at this workshop has since been published in an Encyclopedia of Two-Phase Heat Transfer and Flow III (Vol. 1), World Scientific Publishers. The project also provided the opportunity to include relevant teaching material in graduate-level offerings of Fluid Mechanics and Computational Fluid Dynamics at the UW-Madison Department of Mechanical Engineering.

Modified by: Mario F Trujillo

    Lakshman Anumolu and Mario F. Trujillo
    Mario F Trujillo
    Numerical Simulation of Phase Change
